reasoning: From S5 and S7, while it is correct that CDS payoffs depend on whether the reference company defaults, the claim that all market participants have the same information about default is generally not correct. Therefore, the overall statement is evaluated as false.

plan.title: Extract and restate givens from the statement

plan.title: Identify relevant financial/economic concepts
plan.description: List the key theoretical concepts needed to judge the statement, such as: definition and payoff structure of a credit default swap, role of default events in payoffs, meaning of all market participants having the same information (symmetric information), and how information affects payoffs vs prices.

plan.result: ['Definition and payoff structure of a credit default swap (CDS) – protection buyer/seller, premium payments, contingent payoff upon credit event/default.', 'Nature of a credit event/default trigger – how default of the reference entity determines CDS payoff.', 'Symmetric vs asymmetric information – what it means for all market participants to have the same information about default likelihood.', 'Distinction between payoffs and prices – payoffs depend on realized default events; prices/premia depend on information and beliefs about default probabilities.', 'Market efficiency and information incorporation – how shared information is reflected in CDS spreads rather than changing the contractual payoff formula.', 'Risk transfer/insurance role of CDS – CDS as instruments to transfer credit risk conditional on default.']

step.result: ['Definition and payoff structure of a credit default swap (CDS) – protection buyer/seller, premium payments, contingent payoff upon credit event/default.', 'Nature of a credit event/default trigger – how default of the reference entity determines CDS payoff.', 'Symmetric vs asymmetric information – what it means for all market participants to have the same information about default likelihood.', 'Distinction between payoffs and prices – payoffs depend on realized default events; prices/premia depend on information and beliefs about default probabilities.', 'Market efficiency and information incorporation – how shared information is reflected in CDS spreads rather than changing the contractual payoff formula.', 'Risk transfer/insurance role of CDS – CDS as instruments to transfer credit risk conditional on default.']

candidates.result: Relevant concepts include: (1) Definition and payoff structure of a credit default swap (CDS) as a contract that pays off contingent on a defined credit event, typically default of a reference entity. (2) The role of default events (or specified credit events) as the trigger determining CDS payoffs versus no-payoff states. (3) Symmetric information: the condition where all market participants share the same information set and beliefs about the likelihood of default. (4) Distinction between how information about default risk affects equilibrium prices/spreads of CDS versus the mechanical payoff function, which depends only on the realized default event. (5) Market efficiency/absence of asymmetric information in pricing CDS when all agents have identical information about the reference entity’s credit quality.
